pageContext.title: He’s building a free, open-source solution to make blockchain scalable
pageContext.content:
Beyond the Hype is a series by Jacob Chee, Tech in Asia’s head of blockchain initiatives. He interviews influential personalities who are changing the landscape of their respective fields, with a focus on companies that have the qualities to last through the hype.

This week, we speak with Uri Klarman, CEO of bloXroute. Founded by a team of researchers and systems designers from Northwestern and Cornell universities, including the crypto expert Emin Gun Sirer, bloXroute allows practically every blockchain network to “scale today.”

Can you introduce what problem bloXroute is trying to solve?

Our goal is to solve blockchain’s number one problem: scalability. Bitcoin’s average is 3.3 transactions per second, while Visa, MasterCard, and PayPal combined does about 5,000 transactions per second. The heaviest lift is social media—putting Twitter or Facebook on the blockchain requires 200,000-300,000 transactions per second.

One solution is to increase the size of a block. However, doing so also increases the time it takes for a newly mined block to propagate throughout the entire peer-to-peer system. This is critical because this time window leads to forks: the scenario when two blocks are mined by two different miners at the same time, causing them to compete with each other to become the “true” block.

If you increase the block size by 100x, the time it takes to propagate throughout the entire network actually exceeds the interval time, and the blockhain breaks. So, what you are going to have is a blockchain that has a fork, which then leads to forks of forks, and so on—the blockchain then unravels like a rope and doesn’t convert back to a single blockchain. Eventually the blockchain breaks, as nobody knows which fork to follow. This is the scalability problem.

So bloXroute is a blockchain distribution network (BDN), like an Akamai for blockchain. It is a network of well-optimized servers which have one feature: they receive blocks and broadcast them to the world 1,000x faster.

You can send 1GB block through bloXroute at the same speed it would take 1MB without bloXroute. We allow blockchains to scale by more than a factor of 1,000 out of the gate without them having to change anything.

It seems like a innovative way to solve the scalability problem. What are your team’s credentials?

There are four co-founders, including myself. Professor Emin Gun Sirer is a leading crypto expert who had pivotal roles in characterizing the Nakamoto consensus, the DAO detection, and the aftermath. Professor Aleksandar Kuzmanovic is a net neutrality expert. Our CTO Soumya Basu is most well known for creating the Falcon Network, which has been operational in the Bitcoin network since 2016. I myself am in the final stage of my PhD in computer networks from Northwestern University.

It quickly became apparent to us that scalability is a networking problem that cannot be solved at layer one (with a new blockchain) or at layer two (on top of the blockchain), but at layer zero, underneath the blockchain.

The crypto space is currently filled with great cryptographers and systems designers but very few network-level experts. I think no other team is trying to solve the scalability problem on the network level.

Are blockchains the most important stakeholders for bloXroute?

Yes, and we’re not here to compete with any blockchain—we are enablers. We open source bloXroute.

From our perspective, we see the blockchains developing into a “colosseum of crypto” where they compete with each other to provide real value for real people in the real world. Those that do a good job will prevail, while those who won’t will vanish over time.

For us to gain traction with the blockchains, there are two aspects. First of all, miners already want to use bloXroute, because they know that if they mine a block faster, they can make more money.

The second is for us to show how bloXroute scales in a practical way. We took the code of Bitcoin Unlimited, deployed a large bitcoin network, and will show the number of transactions with and without bloXroute.

If you are open sourced, are you worried about competition?

We never want to be the single point of failure, because what will happen if we go down? We make bloXroute replaceable through a mechanism we call backup networks. You can take our code and deployment script to deploy a backup network which is identical to bloXroute, but is idle and doesn’t incur costs. Essentially, we allow anyone to deploy their own bloXroute.

We don’t worry about competition because of our business model. We provide bloXroute for free to anyone, and we include a non-mandatory, opt-in option to pay us a tiny fraction of the mining fee (say US$0.0005 per transaction). In return, we remove the scalability bottleneck.

It’s going to be hard for a competitor to offer something better than free.

What is your monetization plan?

We want to offer scalability to everyone for free while offering opt-in fee reductions where we get tiny payments, say 5 percent of US$0.01. Assuming we are looking at 30,000 transactions per second, this amounts to US$460 million annually.

Our end game is 200,000-300,000 transactions per second, which amounts to billions of dollars per year. We can’t be making this very large sum of money because people would resent us, so our business model is to converge a win-win-win scenario.

If we increase transactions by more than a factor of 1,000, then users can pay fees that are 100x smaller. Users are happy—that’s the first win.

Miners get fees that are 100x smaller, but they get 1,000x more transactions per second. They make 10x more fees in total, so they are happy. That’s the second win.

Lastly, we figured that if money is pouring out of the crypto ecosystem through bloXroute, it has to pour back into the crypto ecosystem. We decided to build it in the following way: only 50 percent of the tiny payments I mentioned above will go to the company for operations and growth. The other 50 percent goes to a giant reserve of cryptocurrencies that that backs the BLXR, our security token. By allowing the ecosystem to invest in bloXroute through the BLXR token, we are able to give back a large portion of our revenues to the community.

In this way, everybody’s incentives are aligned.

Do you foresee any issues with SEC regarding BLXR?

bloXroute is clearly a security token, and unlike others, we are not trying to mask it as a utility token. We are not concerned because we have made sure we are following the SEC’s regulations to the letter. Our legal counsel, Cooley, has invested months to assure the registration process goes as smoothly as possible.

What do you foresee happening in this industry in the next 10 years?

I think we will see several countries use cryptocurrency as an official currency, and I don’t mean a state-backed cryptocurrency, which has a back door. The weaker economies will probably be the first to do it; they will find crypto easy and cheap to use.

I think we will also see very cool things from the world’s largest tech companies.

Correction (Sep 22, 3:15pm): Clarified the status of Klarman’s PhD and the section on SEC regulations.
